raw_text:
Church urges Nelly show boycott
 
 Church ministers are trying to prevent rapper Nelly performing in Arkansas, saying they do not want his "vile and filthy lyrics" in their town.
 
 More than 20 Jonesboro ministers urged music fans to boycott Nelly's 12 March concert at Arkansas State University in a bid to have it cancelled. "Jonesboro is a wonderful city because of what does not come here," said the Reverend Adrian Rodgers. But a venue spokesman said more than 5,500 tickets had been sold so far.
 
 Mr Rodgers, of the Fullness of Joy Church, said he was concerned about the rapper's lyrics that include references to drugs, sex and violence, and songs that the minister said were demeaning to women. Ministers were worried that bringing such acts to Jonesboro would lead to problems. "Tear the tickets up," Mr Rodgers said. "Do not go and do not allow your children to go."
 
 Tim Dean, director of the Arkansas State University venue, said ticket sales had been brisk. "It would appear that with ticket sales over 5,000, many others have expressed their right to find Nelly's music entertaining and worth spending their time and money on," he said. Nelly has sold more than 30 million singles and albums worldwide, and in September 2004 simultaneously occupied the number one and two positions in the US albums chart. He has had 12 UK hit singles, including Hot in Herre, Dilemma and recent number one Over and Over.
llama3.2:1b: Church ministers are urging Nelly to cancel his March concert at Arkansas State University due to concerns about his lyrics.
The Reverend Adrian Rodgers from the Fullness of Joy Church said Nelly's music includes references to drugs, sex, and violence, making it unsuitable for their town.
More than 5,500 tickets have been sold so far, despite concerns that bringing such acts could lead to problems.
llama3.2:3b: Church leaders in Jonesboro, Arkansas are urging a boycott of Nelly's concert at Arkansas State University, citing his "vile and filthy lyrics" as a reason to prevent him from performing.
Despite concerns, over 5,500 tickets have been sold for the event.

They argue that his lyrics promote drug use, violence, and disrespect towards women and believe it will bring negative consequences to the town.
Despite protests, over 5,000 tickets have been sold for the concert.
Nelly has enjoyed international success with numerous hit songs.

More than 5,500 tickets had been sold so far at the concert venue in Jonesboro.
Mr Rodgers of Fullness of Joy Church was concerned about the lyrics and said that bringing Nelly's acts to Jonesboro would lead to problems for other musicians.
Tim Dean of Arkansas State University said ticket sales were brisk and many others have expressed their right to enjoy Nelly's music.

- Church ministers trying to stop rapper Nelly from performing
- Motivation: lyrics that include drug references
- Jonesboro ministers' advice: boycott the concert
- More than 5,500 tickets sold at the concert venue
- Other musicians' support for Nelly's performances

Ministers warn against allowing children to attend event.
Venue sold out despite concerns about controversial rapper's content.

More than 20 Jonesboro ministers demanded the show be cancelled due to ticket sales exceeding 5,500.
Reverend Adrian Rodgers from Fullness of Joy Church called for tearing up tickets, while venue director Tim Dean defended sales.
Nelly has a global music career with numerous hits.

The ministers are worried about his music's demoralizing impact on women and children.
